"Will accept what I will offer you?"

"Do I have a choice? I must do whatever it takes to survive."

Urso grunted again as his glowing yellow eyes approached her. She felt a nudge at her stomach and was slowly lifted off the ground on onto the great bear's back. He was carrying her away from her old campfire and deeper into the cave. It was so dark that she could not see anything.

"Come then. I shall take you into my refuge."

"Is it warmer there?"

"Nowhere is warm on this world, Krystal. I'm surprised those who sent you would not know the dangers of our land. Even your kin have only survived on this world by hiding in metal machines and rarely venturing outside."

Krystal could only imagine the hardships the Special Operations forces had to endure to live on such a desolate place. Still, this tale spun by Urso about how they drove out his kind from their homes just didn't sit well on her tongue. All members of the Cornerian Forces were bound by duty to never endanger or disturb the sanctity of a planet's inhabitants, the Special Operations were no exception to this rule. But there was no way she could accurately explain such a duty to Urso, she sensed that he was the sort of creature who would not understand such things. His mind seemed too wrapped up in how his people had been wronged and less involved in reasoning.

"I suppose I'll just have to prove to him overtime that we're trustworthy." Krystal thought to herself.

Urso continued to bring her deeper and deeper into his home. Krystal could tell that she was descending underground by the feel in the air. It wasn't getting warmer exactly, but it seemed more stuffy and less fresh.

Finally, the bear came to a stop and gently lowered Krystal down onto a hard surface. Through her limited eyesight in the darkness, she was able to tell that it was some sort of stab or bed made of ice. Krystal quietly crumpled up into a ball with her blanket, she no longer could feel temperatures including cold. She was beginning to sweat profusely, though the very marrow in her bones ached.

Urso disappeared into the shadows once again. It was some time before his great yellow eyes reappeared. Something sharp was place next to Krystal's shivering form.

"What's that?"

"You must eat this herb if you wish to survive."

"What will it do?"

Urso grunted once again, this time it seemed impatient almost. "If you truly have no choice, it will not matter what it does. Make your decision."

She had said there was no choice in the matter. Reaching a shaking hand out for the plant, she grabbed it and tossed it into her mouth wincing as she chewed. Whatever it was, it was extremely bitter and cold, like a sharp blast of the winter winds. Once it was at the bottom of her stomach, however, a new sensation was filling her. Like warm butterflies were passing over her in a wave, heating up every cranny of her body.

As she smiled contently and closed her eyes to drift off into a well earned sleep, Urso grunted approvingly.

"I shall warn you now, little one. When you awaken, you will be in an unfamiliar but safe environment. Do not panic."

"..T-Thank...You..."

With that, Krystal closed her eyes and drifted into peaceful slumber. She awoke...
1351112.title: No Choice

13511121.content:
The first thing Krystal noticed when she opened her eyes was that she was no longer in complete darkness but in a warmly lit cave in, comfortably resting on top of what appeared to be a mattress of straw and twigs. The second thing that came to mind was that she could actually free her arms and legs now. Whatever that bear had given her to eat really worked well, she felt like she could run a marathon now.

A presence on the other end of the cave made Krystal turn her head, and a great big familiar shape came into view.

"Excellent, you are awake."

"Yes, thanks to you. Where am I?"

"The deepest known crevice of our world, beyond the detection of any of your kin's feeble devices. Only those with the powers of the mind would be able to detect us, such as yourself. This is the Lair of the Icewalkers."

"The 'Lair", huh? Well, it's certainly fitting, I'll give you that. Of course, I don't understand what you meant by don't panic-"

Krystal went to sit up in her bed, but was met by some unusual resistance pulling her stomach down. This great weight sent her falling face first into the pile of straw, slightly confused. As she sat up again, her confusion quickly turned into pure terror.

"Wh-Wh-What is this!?"

"This is what I meant by don't panic, little one."

In Krystal's eyes, she could hardly have been called little anymore. Her once perfect figure honed by years of martial arts practicing and constant training had been completely ruined. Her stomach had extended a good foot away from her body as her breasts, which were certainly bigger than before, were resting comfortably on top of it. Every part of her seemed fatter to her, even her arms and legs.

"What happened to me!?" Krystal demanded.

"I saved your life."

"Saved my life!?" This could only be considering saving her life if she had been starving in a desert for forty days. Krystal felt disgusting and huge like a hippopotamus.

"The herb you ate was no ordinary herb. It is specially prepared medicine that we use to bolster our young's body heat and mass. We consider it our most sacred plant, I did not choose to give it to a stranger such as yourself lightly."

Krystal was sure she had offended Urso now, but was still freaking out over her bodily change. "Couldn't you have just brought me here!? I mean this place seems much warmer than it was in the cave!"

"It only seems that way because of the herb I gave you. With the storm blowing outside on the surface, it's most likely even colder than it was the day I rescued you."

Urso had kindly left Krystal's belongings in a neat heap on the side of her straw mattress. After digging around her remaining supplies, she found her portable thermometer and promptly shrieked at the number it displayed. "There's no way! It's -50 Celsius in here!"

"Typical arctic storm temperatures in our home. I repeat, had I not given you that herb you'd be a frozen corpse right now."

Krystal frowned and gazed glumly at her gigantic stomach bulging out beneath her Arwing uniform. This was going to take at least three months of dieting and constant exercising to burn off. "I...I understand. Thank you, and I'm sorry Urso. I just...This wasn't what I expected when you said you'd save me."

"I suppose a greater warning would have been more appropriate on my part, so I apologize too. There was really no other way and no time to waste. If I hadn't given you the herb and treated you here, you would have been gone for certain. It already took two days for you to awaken."

"Two days," Krystal thought to herself. "Fox and the guys probably think I'm in trouble, or worse..."

Krystal rose to her feet with some difficultly, considering her new girth, and hobbled over to her equipment to begin packing things up. She'd have to at least find a way to contact her friends and let them know she was alive.

"What are you doing?"

"Packing my things and finding my communicator. I need to get to the surface and tell my friends I'm alright."

"You're going to stay right where you are."

There wasn't anything sinister in the bear's tone of voice, only a commanding presence. Nevertheless, Krystal prepared her staff in case she had to fight her way out. With this extra weight, it would be difficult but she'd have to manage somehow.

She calmly but firmly warned the bear. "I'm not staying here, Urso. I need to speak to my friends."

"If you go up to the surface now, you will die. I did not save your life just so you could throw it away again. Do you know what's going on above us now?"

She lowered her staff. "What?"

"The entire earth is being covered by layer upon layer of snow and ice. The great storm is upon us, the terrible phenomena that happens only every few years. Even the mightiest of our kind who have attempted to face the storm on the surface have perished from the bitter cold and blinding winds. It is a frozen apocalypse in the world above."

"How long do you expect me to sit here and wait?"

"It will take five days at least for the worst of the storm to pass-"

"Five days!?"

"-I suspect during that time your friends will be able to look for you anyway. Even with their machines and metal monsters, your kin were unable to venture out into the great storm. They too bunkered into their homes as we must do for a time until it is safe again to walk the surface."

"Then when the storm ends, will you let me return to the surface?"

Urso shifted around uncomfortably again. "Yes. But I have a request to make."

Krystal sighed, but nodded. "I suppose I do owe you for saving my life. What do you need?"

"You are the first of your kind to be taken into our Lair. This is because you are the first of your kin to use mind words to speak with us, you're the first one to communicate with us. We desire our homes that your kin stole from us. When the storm settles and it is safe to venture the wasteland, I wish to take you to your brother's metal home and reason with them. If you do this for us, I will consider our debt paid in full."

She laughed slightly. "That works out just fine for me. I was planning on visiting them anyway, and you can show me the way even. There's just one problem though, how am I supposed to get there without my Arwing?"

"I said I would teach you the ways of the Icewalkers, and I plan to. For the next five days, you will learn to become an Icewalker."

"And that's a figurative statement, right?"

"No, you must physically become an Icewalker if you plan on surviving the trip to your kin's home."

For a minute, Krystal didn't quite believe what this bear was asking her to do. She had never heard of anyone ever literally transforming into a bear, but then again she had never heard of a herb that could protect the eater from cold and fatten them up in such a short time. Part of her was screaming at her to not do it, but her more reasonable made a convincing argument. Without Urso, she would have been dead.

"Is it permanent?"

"No, it is simply..."
13511121.title: A Big Request

135111211.content:
"It is simply a few days of training as an Icewalker, along with a steady diet of the herb I gave you."

"The herb is the key then?"

"In a manner of speaking. As I said to you before, this herb is one of our most sacred icons. It comes from the deep roots of the only known plant to grow on our world known as Ymirwood. This lair holds the last bastion of our holy tree, and it is through the herbs created from its roots that our people have been able to survive on this barren world for as long as we have."

Krystal patted her protruding stomach. "Yes, I can imagine it's qualities have helped your kind live through the harsh winters."

"Legends say that our people were once like yours, small and unsuited for the winters of the planet. It was through the Ymirwood that our people were saved. Some say it was the planet itself that reached out and spared us."

Krystal nodded along, but in the back of her mind she had her doubts. She had heard of a species adapt to a planet before over the course of a period of time, but there had never been a case of a planet adapting for the species itself. She didn't wish to betray Urso's trust in her, however, she much desired to examine the qualities of this herb he had given her.

"In any case, come. We have little time if you wish to be prepared for the journey to the defiler's- your kin's- hole."

Krystal nodded and resumed gathering up her things to follow Urso, she was regretting burning her backpack now especially with the extra weight she had been putting one. She followed Urso out of the cave with all her belongings on top of her stomach, waddling to catch up to his great strides as best as she could. He led her down a long rock hallway filled with unusual cave paintings of bears, men, and all manners of horrible looking snow creatures. Krystal didn't bother to take a look at them in case she became too distracted and dropped one of her items.

When Urso came to a stop at the end of the hall, Krystal only then dared to glance up.

"Behold. These are the halls of the Icewalker."

Hall was an inappropriate word at least from Krystal's perspective. The cave had opened up into a full blown chamber, fully lit with fires along the walls. The alcove they were now in was at least one hundred feet tall with an almost menacing statue of a bear in the chamber center stretching up the entire length with bubbling waters down below them. Along the walls were multiple holes, which Krystal assumed leaded into more hallways like the one they had just been in. Most noticeably was the amount of white furred bears lurking everywhere in the chamber. At a glance, there had to be at least a thousand of them.

"How in the world did you manage to build all of this?" Krystal finally found her voice after a moment of speechlessness.

"The truth is, we didn't. This, along with the Ymirwood were all found here ages ago. We believe this place is as old as the planet itself."

"Maybe the cavern itself is, but that statue is definitely hand made." Krystal thought aloud.

Urso grunted uncomfortably. "Regardless. We must venture down into the lowest chamber, where the elders and the Ymirwood await to meet you. Once they have heard your plea, they will allow you to begin your training as an Icewalker."

"You mean they haven't already?"

Urso did not answer, and instead continued towards a ramp in the cave wall. Krystal clumsily followed with her items in hand nearly tripping over her own two feet. It was much more difficult to walk like this than she expected. Along the way down into the pools of steam, Krystal sensed that she was being watched. She looked around the walls of the chamber to see that every single pair of yellow eyes were on her.

"They're staring at me." she whispered to Urso.

"Indeed, so they are."

The bears treated her with...
135111211.title: Training Begins

1351112111.content:
At the bottom of the chamber and at the foot of the bear statue was a grand looking entrance right between the statue's hind legs. The doorway opened up into what Krystal assumed was an assembly. There was a stage in the back raised above small stone benches all facing it. On the stage sat three of the oldest looking bears Krystal had ever seen, with the most ancient looking one sitting in the middle with beads tied into its fur.

"The Exiled approaches," echoed a new hoarser voice in Krystal's mind. "And he comes bearing one of the Defilers. Hardly a welcoming sight for your first visit to the Lair in years."

"Indeed, it has been some time most honored elders." Urso's familiar voice filled her head now. "The past is past, I come now with tidings of a hopeful future. This young may yet restore our rightful glory and bring justice."

"That abomination!?" Rumbled an even deeper voice which Krystal suspected was coming from the fat bear to the right. "That filth would see us driven out of our homes before helping us! Toss it out into the storm!"

"I have already begun to evoke the Right of the Icewalker." replied Urso.

The hall suddenly filled with angry roars and growls. Krystal had not been paying attention behind her, but several dozen bears had entered the assembly as well. All of them had the same angry glare on their faces. All of them were looking directly at her.

"Enough," called out the center voice. "The penalty for such an act is-"

"Exile, something that you had already placed on me, brother. That still didn't stop me from returning home, did it? You let me walk right in. If you still hold any hope towards me, then listen. All of you."

The hall grew uncomfortably quiet as Urso stepped forward and onto the stage.

"I have a solution, one that will work this time. I know the hatred of the Defilers still burns in your very souls, but this one is different. She can help us, she will help us. She has already agreed to undergo the Right."

"And what trust can we place in this Defiler? How can we be so certain that she speaks the truth? What if this is another trick?"

"If she betrays us, I will place the Ritual of Yorn on myself."

Whatever it was Urso had said, it caused even more commotion than revealing that he had given Krystal the herb already. This didn't seem like angry growls though, more concerned or awed. Krystal wasn't quite sure how, but she was able to sense their tones and feelings through their roars.

"If you remain so confident, the Elders will grant you their blessing, though strained as it may be. You are granted access to Ymirwood, dismissed."

All three of the elder bears rose and stepped out of the assembly, as did most of the audience. Urso and Krystal continued to remain behind. She was desperately trying to keep up with what had just happened.

"You didn't say you were exiled," she said to Urso.

"You never asked."

"I take it this Ritual of Yorn thing is bad?"

Urso paused, trying to find the right words. "Exile is merely exile. One can still return to the sloth if one proves himself, we are so few that this is permitted. The Ritual is...More final. It is abandoning all worldly possessions and venturing into the frozen wastes alone. It is a death sentence, a long cold death sentence."

Krystal suddenly felt cold, remembering wandering around the snow covered plains like it was a dream. How close had she come to death?

"Do you understand, Krystal? I put my life on the line because you must succeed, because we must succeed. Once you go forward with me, you may not turn back."

~

"The actual process is quite simple, little one." said a shriveled looking old bear that sounded like a female to Krystal, though she couldn't be any judge. "Lay down please on the slab and we can begin."

Krystal obeyed, laying flat on her back with her massive stomach in the air. She wasn't sure, but it felt as if she had gotten heavier since this morning. The budge that was her belly seemed so huge to her now.

"You're coming along quite nicely," continued the old bear. "Have you had your root today?"

"No, I-"

"Well, what are you waiting for? Remember, you must never go a day without the herb else you could end up ruining the whole process."

The crone bear set down a plate of blue roots at Krystal's side, she grab one and silently chewed on it. "This all seems far-fetched, what exactly are these herbs doing to me?"

"Stimulating your body and growing it. You have a lot of catching up to do if you want to make the trip to the Defiler's Grounds. And Urso entrusted you to me, so I'm going to make sure you're ready. Now swallow that root!"

Krystal obeyed and gagged on the taste of the bitter herb. "What must I do to be prepared?"

"First step...?
1351112111.title: Clearance

13511121112.content:
"Sit up," commanded the old female bear.

Krystal obeyed, though she admitted that it was getting harder to do so with her massive gut. There was also a growing warmth spreading from her belly to other parts of her body, just like before though this was more pronounced. Despite a massive weight dragging her down, Krystal was able to stand on her two feet with little difficultly.

"I feel hot," she said to the bear.

"Indeed, the growth should begin over the course of the day. You'll be even bigger then."

"How big will I get?"

"As large as any other of our kind."

Krystal gulped. She tried to imagine herself as big as Urso and her mind simply couldn't process it. All the bears here were at least ten feet in height, even the older bear in front of her was sitting at around nine feet. Getting fatter was one thing, it would be another entirely to grow into a giant.

"This way."

The old bear motioned her to follow into a rather loud part of the caverns. When Krystal arrived she saw that it opened up into another large chamber with dozens of little growls inside. Krystal nervously stepped towards the ledge and saw an amazing sight.

"Baby bears?"

"Those are our cubs, yes."

The chamber before her was like a playroom for at least fifty different tiny bears, at least tiny in comparison to the adults. Each cub was nearly five feet tall, nearing the height of Krystal herself. They were all tackling each other and now that they were closer, Krystal could hear their childish laughter in her mind.

"Well, go on," the old bear nudged Krystal in the back, closer to the edge.

"W-Wait," Krystal scrambled to keep her balance on the ice. "What am I supposed to do?"

But it was too late, Krystal slipped on the edge and slid down the ledge like a slide straight for the cubs. "Walk like a Icewalker. Wrestle with them and learn to use our great strength."

Dragging her fluffy tail on the ground, Krystal skidded to a halt in front of a rather bulky cub with a strange black moon marking at its forehead. It turned to greet her were with wide green eyes.

"Hi!" shouted a kid-female voice. "Who are you?"

Unlike the adult bears, the children seemed to show no hostility to Krystal whatsoever. There was a wide-eyed curiosity as Krystal sat up to brush her butt off, causing the cub to back off.

"Don't be afraid," said Krystal. "My name is Krystal and--"

"Why are you angry?"

"Huh?"

"You're standing up like that, are you angry?"

"Right," Krystal whispered to herself. "Bears only stand on their hide legs when they're angry. Walk like a bear."

Krystal carefully leaned over and got down on all fours, which instantly caused the cub to return to her and smell her. She tensed up, hoping not to scare her new friend.

"Hehe, you smell like fruit," said the moon-cub.

"Thank you," said Krystal, struggling to keep her head raised at the cub and she repeated. "My name is Krystal."

"I'm Tunglio!"

"You're quite fortunate, outsider," said the old bear crone's voice as she approached from the side. "Tunglio is actually the daughter of one of our elders. Treat her with respect."

Krystal nodded as Tunglio got closer to her. "Is Krystal here to play?"

"She is here to learn how to be one of us. She has begun the Rite of the Icewalker and needs to study our ways, starting with learning how to physically behave like one of us."

"Cool!" Tunglio got even closer to Krystal's face. "You'll be like a big sister! Does that you'll wrestle with us?"

"W-What?" The thought of Krystal taking on this bear, even if Tunglio was still a child, would be a daunting task without her staff, which she left back in her bedroom.

It only made matters worse when the old bear said. "Absolutely. The first step in her transformation is testing her strength."

Without warning, Tunglio immediately jumped at Krystal, trying to pin her to the ground. Krystal reacted as quickly as she could, but was ultimately defeated by the cub's great weight. Laughing, Tunglio got off Krystal as the fox girl sat up, gasping for air.

"How am I supposed to beat her when she's twice as heavy as me?" Krystal asked the crone bear.

The old bear gave a a huff. "You must defeat Tunglio by the end of the day or we will not proceed. Fight or give up. Walk like a Icewalker."

Krystal grunted and got back to all fours again. This would be easier if she was used to walking around like this, instead her back was already killing her from bending over and holding up the great weight on her belly. The other cubs were gathering around her now, looking at the strange overweight fox before them.

"Are you going to surrender?" asked the old bear.

Krystal gritted her teeth. She had a mission here other than survival. She couldn't back down now, even if the task seemed impossible. Urso was putting his life on the line in order for Krystal to make peace with his people and the Special Operation forces, and she owned him for her survival. Even if it meant becoming a bear, even if only temporary, she wouldn't back out of a life debt.

"No, I'll learn."

"Good," the old bear sounded pleased.

Over the course of the day Krystal...
13511121112.title: Walk Like a Bear

Kyle: Well, simply put...

142231.content:
Krystal lied in her room on the floor. With her hands over her face, she couldn't help, but think. She wanted to leave Star Fox. It was fun while it lasted, but to her, now the magic's worn off. There were barely any missions she could go by herself or anything else to do when on breaks. She and Fox were having a relationship, but after two weeks, she told him let's be friends again. Fox took that personally and although he never tells her or his team-mates, he sneaks off of the base to find some girls to be with. She just wanted to leave Star Fox to do other things, but she thought to herself: how could she leave? She didn't want to quit because her friends would think she didn't like them. She wanted a good reason to leave so when she does, she'll say good-bye to her friends.

Taking a break in the shower, Krystal was washing herself and as she looked at her slender body, she touched her belly with her fingers and thought of the best way to leave. If she was out of shape, they'd have to let her go. Drying off her fur and putting on a towel over her body, she went to her lap-top and typed in how to get a bigger belly. To her surprise she found a website that was shipping...

info.brief_description: Krystal, from Star Fox, grows big in a couple of ways.
info.description:
Krystal starts getting big, ether by weight gain or other ways.

A few rules:
Neither Krystal or Fox can die in the story
stick with the storyline, no going into random stuff
no love interest between Krystal and Wolf
and lastly no swearing, unless you have to.
try to make the story longer than 20 chapters

Other than that, anything goes.
Have fun!
Please add new chapters or else the story can't continue.
